SAY NO TO DEBT

SAY NO TO MORTGAGE

61905088

save EVERYTHING

This. You bought latest iPhone? You’re poor!

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61905232
>>61905096
The rate on my mortgage that I got in 2020 is now lower than the rate I can get from a HYSA.
I get 3% cash back on every credit card purchase I make and pay 0% interest. Whenever I get a new credit card, I usually get a $200 bonus cash back, plus 0% APR for 12+ months.
Low/no interest debt is fucking awesome. You are a retard who sucks at math and long term planning.

61905243
>>61905079
Have literally done all of this. Just on a smaller scale. My home and land are paid for(besides taxes), only 1 acre, manufactured home. I bought my truck 10 years ago cash, I still drive it every day. I have 1 credit card for "emergencies", I dont have to work and I can smoke weed all day. I'm as happy as I can imagine, but by any standard I'm poor

>>61905079

61908034
>>61905088

61908045
>>61905232
No one ever got rich from credit card perks. I'm not arguing that interest-free debt is cool but don't act like credit cards are how you get wealthy.

61908654
>>61905079
Horrible advice. Buy with credit cards that offer rewards, then pay them off in full every month before due date. Im up to 40 dols in cashback rewards just using cards instead of my debit, then paying off the bill with money I was going to use to buy the stuff in the first place. Literal free money and my credit score has been soaring. Fuck wish id done this a decade ago.

61908821
>>61905079
People meme on Dave a lot but I don't think he's that bad, I just don't think Dave is really meant for people who can control their spending. If you even somewhat understand money and you have a healthy savings account, good 401k, and don't have a ton of debt you aren't his target audience. His target audience is people who -
>are 21-50 years old
>have a $1.5k a month car loan for 84 months
>buy Labubus and other weird shit
>can't control their spending
>have 5 credit cards
>have no savings or long term investments
>make $15 an hour

OP

>28
>$290.000
>5.5%
>46,000 down
>1,900 sq ft

First time homeowner. Never did crypto, not my game. All advice I can give you is buy precious metals and commodities. Also CD's are based. I've escaped rentoid hell. I'm out, and I'll never return. Good luck fags, I wish you the best. Low ball these boomer fucks.

61908662

61908663

>locked down in 1 place
>have to fix everything
>monthly mortgage payments are the same as renting anyway
>have to pay to fix your own things
>ordinances
>property tax anyway after done with mortgage payments

enjoy, you're now a rentoid to a bank, anon

>have to pay to fix your own things
Yeah, I did that while renting. I had shit landlords that refused to fix things correctly. But now I have knowledge of fixing shit
>ordinances
Yeah, but at least now I can put a fucking nail in the wall and paint it whatever color I want
>property tax anyway after done with mortgage payments
Don't care, no multi-thousand dollar payment every month.

I will NEVER be a slave to a bank.

25

People can tell when you're struggling to act, pretend, trying to follow a script, etc. People are pretty good at detecting insincerity. The sheer number of dipshits that believe whatever their favorite Youtuber says might suggest otherwise, but that's really just a testament to how prolific skilled actors have become.
You can detect "soul" from "soulless" in content the same way. You spot AI images the same way, and you used to spot Photoshopped images the same way.
>I thought i was acting normalfag and friendly
Yeah, people can tell you're putting an inordinate amount of effort into acting "normal". They notice that you're not comfortable, and that makes them suspicious. It's a catch-22. You want to follow the social script, but you adhere to your image of it too strictly. Because you don't actually, in action, understand it. This is because you were not "properly socialized" as a child <- that's what people mean when they talk about socializing children.

item.title: FED ENDS THE SILVER — 9 replies — 36.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
FED ENDS THE SILVER

Open thread • Replies: 9 • Updated: 2026-02-27 01:42 UTC

OP

Rock collecting is not investing, and all dwarves flooding the precious metal threads will end up rugged just like the last time. Yes, I'm jinxing it.

Can I order buy anything with silver — like I can do with Bitcoin near instantly, just sending the money to someone in Japan in a flash? No? Then your silver is not real money, you might as well collect Pokémon cards because it is unironically easier to turn them into cash.

The precious metal fad killed bitcoin, there is no explanation for the wave of liquidations besides whales "diversifying" their asset.

nobody does this

think that people actually towards stocks instead of bottomed-out BTC because it makes them feel more adult in their boo…

Open thread • Replies: 5 • Updated: 2026-02-27 01:37 UTC

OP

think that people actually towards stocks instead of bottomed-out BTC because it makes them feel more adult in their boomer-accustomed mentality

Early replies (first 3)

61908552
>>61908521
Yes, I am not ashamed of it. I always bought your shit currency that is so good that you spend every single day with your blood pressure elevated because it might rug and send you straight to tending tables.

Bitcoin doesn't bring you peace, no matter what you do. For that alone, it is not a good "investment".

But /biz/ is not ready for the conversation. They will talk down ETFs (basically the evolution of buying shares in the discretionary manner of the past) and bonds, while not ackowledging that what Bitcoin might earn them in cash they'll never collect, it will cost in years of life lost looking at charts.

61908561
>>61908521
Yeah. That's why, despite over a decade having passed...
We're still early. Isn't that crazy?

61908575
>>61908561
the slow yet stead rise is the strongest proof that it's going to stick around for a long while

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61908579
>>61908561
Even when we're late Bitcoin will have utility. Its the natural evolution of currencies as a technology, and it mogs the fuck out of traditional ones, especially because its decentralized, censorship proof and deflationary. It isn't traded as a currency currently, and it has a bumpy volatile road ahead of it until people realize it isn't a tech stock. But it just works, and there's nothing that can stop it short of global EMPs, and even then its temporary.
Boomers don't understand Bitcoin or why its important, so they just hate it.
Jews understand Bitcoin and thus hate it as it is a threat to their world domination model.
Retards don't understand Bitcoin and thus hate it as they probably fomo'd one time at an ATH and got burned, or are just a seething metalbaggie that got sick of hearing people get rich from holding it (price action has absolutely nothing to do with the technology itself btw)

61908801
>>61908552
It's called diversifying retard.
You worry about BTC dropping 50% because you aren't diversified.
I own ETFs, Individual Stocks, Gold, and T-Bills in addition to crypto.
I set a specific target percentage of my net worth in crypto so if crypto goes down, i buy to get it back to that percentage, if crypto percentage goes up due to bull cycle, I sell some crypto and buy more traditional assets.
It's called rebalancing your portfolio. I'm not looking at charts all day, I'm not stressed when BTC drops 50%, and with decades of experience, I just react to it like a robot now with the rebalancing.

item.title: $SEV - Aptera. Electric car you never have to plug in — 68 replies — 43.5/hr
item.content:encoded:
$SEV - Aptera. Electric car you never have to plug in

Open thread • Replies: 68 • Updated: 2026-02-27 00:08 UTC

OP

This is a risky startup company, but FINALLY this year they are shipping their product. This summer, in fact. They just finished a final round of dilution a month ago, and the stock just hit a critical point where it’s actively in recovery.

It’s a real car, a product that *will* ship that nerds are geeking out about, and it appears now someone big is starting to slowly acquire it.

The first model will have its flaws, but it’s an electric car that can run off the solar panels on its roof. No one has ever done that before.

And the entire fucking company’s marketcap, this Nasdaq company, is $70 million.

You’re welcome.

(Disclosure: I obviously own some moderate sized bags of this, as should you)

Early replies (first 3)

61902124
Go look the shit up on YouTube and do some research. Tech bros will buy out the first line of these as fun geek toys, and by the second and third iterations, it’s gonna start getting serious. The big boys (aka Tesla) cannot afford to let this company get too large under their toes. They’ll acquire the stock and buy them out before that happen. That’s my thesis, anyway. The company’s not perfect, it has issues. But it’s worth more than $70 million for damn sure.

61902143
>>61902111
I believe that oil,nat gas, nuclear energy, clean coal is going to make a comeback, and that the "green" stuff wont be " cool" anymore, I avoid betting on anyting "green". >>61904656
Jane Street are fucking based and the only reason anyone might think otherwise is because they don't have actual convictions in the market value for their shitcoin/commodity or they're jealous that they're so good at squeezing money out of market cap balloons before they pop.
Before you invest in ANYTHING you should ask yourself if Jane Street could fuck it. Matt Levine has a great quote on them from when they made money off the collapse of Terra.
>"I am sorry. But if you go to Jump Trading and Jane Street and say “hello, I have an unregulated poorly designed mechanism that could lead to $50 billion of market value collapsing overnight, would you like to trade with me,” they are going to say yes, but their eyes are going to light up, you know? If at Time 0 you give them an extremely gameable system that can produce billions of dollars of profit, at Time 10 your system is going to be a smoking wreckage and they are going to have billions of dollars of profit. That’s their whole job, you know? I couldn’t tell you in advance what all the intermediate steps will be, and in fact in hindsight I cannot tell you what the intermediate steps actually were, how Jump and Jane Street made money off the collapse of Terra. But as a heuristic, I mean, come on. Terra was like “hello we have a balloon full of money, here is a pin, dooooooon’t pop the balloon.” Guess what!"
